Docs for moving future client-side settings out of settings.py

Client-side settings should not be stored in HORIZON_CONFIG
in settings.py. For example, things like page size, alert fade delays,
modal backdrop type, etc. This mixes up frontend and backend settings.

Instead, we should have one settings file for client-side

and one for server-side.

the legacy options from settings.py, but for the future,
they should be stored in 'horizon/static/framework'.

The client-side settings are in:

subject: WIP: Convert the Heat stack creation wizard to a workflow
commit_message:
WIP: Convert the Heat stack creation wizard to a workflow

The current Heat stack creation wizard is implemented using two seperate
forms.  This results in the inability to move back and forth between steps
in the creation process without first cancelling the entire wizard and
starting over.  This change aims to improve the user experience on this
page by converting this wizard to a Horizon 'workflow'.  Being that it is a
workflow, users will have the ability to freely move back and forth between
steps to modify previous fields without cancelling the entire process and
starting over, much like the current implementations of many of the other
resource creation wizards (Instances, Images, Networks, etc.).

Some client side JS had to written in order to dynamically create fields
in step 2 of the workflow based on template parameters entered in step 1.
It is a bit of a workaround to the traditional implementation of a workflow,
which is why I imagine that it was not done as a workflow in the first place.
That being said, the workflow functions exactly as all other Horizon workflows
and still provides the same functionality as the existing Heat stack creation
wizard.

Co-Authored-By: Justin Pomeroy <jpomero@us.ibm.com>
Implements: blueprint launch-stack-workflow

subject: Add multi role test possibility to integr. tests
commit_message:
Add multi role test possibility to integr. tests

Adding possibility to run tests within perspective of multiple user roles.

I have changed the behaviour of BaseTestCase, nows it redirects user
to login page automatically - as this is probably requirement for all
tests(in case of login test one needs to be on login page as well).
I have added decorators that enables to specify user role within
which test should be executed when ran within MultiUserTestCase.

All test methods will now have suffix that says within which role was
test executed.(Accept for login_url test and tests that inherits from
BaseTestCase class generally)

I have added following classes:

* MetaStandardUserTestCase - automatically adds 'as_standard_user' suffix to
                             test methods name.

* MetaAdminUserTestCase - automatically adds 'as_admin_user' suffix to test
                          methods name.

* MetaMultiUserTestCase - spawns two instances of each test with
                          appropriate suffix unless decorator is used.

* LoggedInTestCase - class for test cases that needs log out in
                     tearDown.

* AdminUserTesCase - ensures that test is executed within admin user
                     role.

* StandardUserTestCase - ensures that test is executed within standard
                         user role.

* MultiUserTestCase - ensures that test is executed within correct user,
                      this depends on test method suffix.

Decoratos:

* admin_user_only_testcase - makes test method executable only within
                             admin user context

* standard_user_only_testcase - makes test method executable only within

Federated Identity Mapping

Federated identity management closely works with Keystone service to
authenticate and authorise users. Federation uses attributes provided by
identity providers and translates it to attributes recognised by
OpenStack.  Federation has integrated functionality called attribute
mapping that maps attributes obtained from identity providers and maps
them to attributes that can be used in OpenStack cloud. Attribute mapping
engine uses mapping rules to map these attributes. Mapping rules are
stored in database along with mapping ID to identify these rules.

This interface allows the user to list, create, update and delete
particular mapping rules in order to reduce workload for the
administrators and reduce security risks that are associated with
issuing provisional identities. The interface should be easily used
and understood even by novice administrators.

subject: [WIP] Refactor Resource to better serve Proxy
commit_message:
[WIP] Refactor Resource to better serve Proxy

Through a series of attempts we haven't been able to sufficiently solve
the issue of what were called "path_args" in the past, somewhat of a
relic of the time before we had the Proxy layer. "path_args" made a lot
of sense when there was only the Resource and the usage was almost
entirely through the classmethods on it, back when command-line example
scripts were the primary example of usage.

As things have grown in the year-plus since that time, we have bolted a
great higher-level interface on a lower-level interface that was stuck
in an older use-case. It was most recently a problem when we had
resource.prop types that accepeted Resource types, which both there and
elsewhere meant it became significantly harder, if not impossible, to
have nested Resources. An example of this is how ServerInterface is a
resource that depends on Server.

This approach strips Resource down to a public API of only create, get,
update, delete, head, find, and list methods. Resource subclasses are
still constructed in the same manner, though the naming of what were
"props" is now slightly different, but more clear. Additionally, through
that change comes a more clear user experience for URI parameters, aka,
"path_args". This also paves the way for more clarity on query
parameters which work in much the same way, although they haven't been
fully explored.

As the changing of this class has pretty far reaching effects, it will
exist temporarily in the "resource2" module. The first change will be to
introduce the module itself in standalone, and then we will change each
service independent of the others. Subsequent changes should not be too
disruptive, mostly in the form of renaming things like resource.prop to
resource.Body, and the like.

There is a fairly major side effects of the implementation of this class
that is behaviorally different from the initial Resource implementation.
Previously, any-and-all data sent into a Resource initializer would be
tracked internally on the Resource instance and then sent to the server
*even if it did not correspond to a resource.prop on the class*.
Ultimately this would have become a problem as servers are becoming more
strict about what they receive, but this implementation makes no
allowance for so-called loose data to be entered. If there is no
component attribute for an argument to be sent to the server, or one
received from the server, it will not exist as an attribute of the
Resource. Currently said data is just dropped entirely, but it could be
logged, or perhaps a strict/loose mode could be engaged to warn or
otherwise fail when unexpected data is entered. Ultimately, this
behavior had to happen. In the near term it may mean that the SDK
doesn't work exactly as it had in previous versions, but that will just
mean updating Resource definitions to match what is truly expected or
given by the server.

Change-Id: If4d07b8d617f53be5a86c0c8733166e68e9d21ad

commit_message:
Work around stall in py34 unit tests

Sometimes the gate-based-runs of the py34 unit tests will timeout.
There are probably multiple factors that contribute to this but one
of them is that:

test_fixtures.TestOSAPIFixture.test_responds_to_version will block
in epoll() under python3.x for a long time (on the order of minutes)

This patch provides a rather hacky workaround: the request against
the api server is put in its own greenthread. It would be better to
figure out why the blocking is happening, but it seems likely it is
just another one of eventlets weird deadlocks when doing io on
both ends of a stream in the same process. eventlet + python3
doesn't appear to be completely mature yet.

This does mean that unless eventlet matures soon, when we start
using python3 to run the functional tests those tests will be
unreliable because what this test is testing is that the fixtures
used in functional tests will work as expected. The failures say
"no, they will not". However, in the interests of getting the
existing tests working in a way that doesn't block the gate

This makes all metricd workers constently waiting to acquire
the object lock to rm_xattr or get_xattrs.

This change is a try to reduce the lock contention on the 'measures' object.

To list pending measures with just have to do the difference between

while we compute the new set of metrics to be done by a worker.

to keep the same task name and create a sequence of execution
for it, e.g.:
make database deploy on primary controller first

database:
  ...
  groups: [primary-controller, controller]
  cross-depends:
    name: database
    role: primary-controller
  ...

instead of

primary-database:
  ...
  groups: [primary-controller]
  ...

database:
  groups: [controller]
  cross-depends:
    name: primary-database

But this might introduce a loop where task depends
on itself on the same node.

The commit below introduces an additional condition for this
to not yield such looping dependencies when they are met.

This behaviour is not triggered for cross-dependencies referring to
role:self as they are essentially an extension of required and
required_for varinats with support of regular expressions.

This commit also fixes some tests that had such loops defined in unit
tests, thus failing with this new condition enabled.

Fix compatibility mode of backup jobs scheduling

While testing interoperability of Liberty and Mitaka services I've found
two problems with backup jobs scheduling when running in non-scalable
mode (this happens when we run mixed Liberty and Mitaka c-bak services,
so during the live upgrade).

First of all when passing volume.host into scheduling we don't strip it
from backend and pool parts (@backend#pool), so in multi-backend
environment scheduling doesn't match backup host names and that clue is
silently ignored.

Second problem is that we don't pass the target volume's host into the
scheduling when restoring the volume. This means that we don't schedule
the jobs exactly the old way and it may happen that Liberty's
cinder-backup will receive restore request with a target volume he don't
have access to.

This commit sorts both problems out. Please note that this is very
low-risk, as it affects only this non-scalable mode, which without this
is broken anyway.

subject: Huawei: Implement v2.1 replication
commit_message:
Huawei: Implement v2.1 replication

This patch implements the v2.1 replication in the HuaweiDriver.
All function in replication v2 are removed. A new function,
failover_host, is added to support failover between backends.

When error occurred on primary backend, you can failover to
the secondary backend. But it's strongly recommended to recover
the primary backend.

After failover backend, the operations on the secondary backend
are limited. A simple example, if you create a new volume on
secondary, after failback, it can't be used. So, You should not
do that, such as create, delete, extend volumes, etc.

But you can detach volume if it's in in-use status, then do
attach to vm to make replication volumes R&W.

The configuration for v2.1 is almost the same as v2. Except that,
only one backend configuration is needed. A simple example as
follows:

[replica]
volume_driver =
    cinder.volume.drivers.huawei.huawei_driver.HuaweiISCSIDriver
    cinder_huawei_conf_file = /etc/cinder/cinder_huawei_conf.xml
    replication_device = backend_id:huawei-replica-1,
        storage_pool:pool_1,
        san_address:san_url_1;san_url_2,
        iscsi_default_target_ip:192.168.1.100,
        san_user:admin,san_password:passwd

Change-Id: Ib555707e9751f78ce00c9dcdbbe370a18ed0ae6c
Closes-Bug: #1556450

subject: Fix Python 3 issues
commit_message:
Fix Python 3 issues

* Replace 123L with 123. On Python 3, 123L raises a SyntaxError.
* Replace unicode with six.text_type.
* Replace dict.keys() with list(dict.keys()) to get a list
  on Python 3.
* Replace dict.values()[0] with list(dict.values())[0]. On Python 3,
  dict.values() returns a view which is not iterable.
* Replace d=dict(d.items() + d2.items()) with d.update(d2). On
  Python 3, dict.items() returns a view which doesn't support a+b
  operator. Using update() is simpler, there is no need to duplicate
  the first dict.
* Replace (generator).next() with next(generator)
* ResponseBodyIterator: add a __next__() alias to the next(). On
  Python 3, iterators must have a __next__() method. The alias allows
  to support Python 2 and Python 3.
* ResponseBodyIterator.__iter__(): replace self.next() with
  next(self).

subject: Enables the notification tests in py3
commit_message:
Enables the notification tests in py3

There are two things being fixed here:
 - In py3 a class is unhashable if it defines an __eq__, but doesn't
   define a __hash__. testtools.TestCase does this so adding the
   TestCase's methods into the set of methods to be called fails. The
   fake Manager class was created to bypass the issue since objects are
   hashable by default.
 - In py3 unbound methods are no longer a special object. They are
   treated the same an any other function object (note I don't mean
   instance methods). Because of this the TypeError is no longer raised
   when calling an unbound method without a class instance. To catch the
   same error in py3 we can get rid of the *args and spell out the
   arguments. This way when the method is called it will get a
   TypeError, since not all of the arguments will be passed in (no self,
   because it's not being called with an instance).

An unused callback method was also removed.
